discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
End-to-End QoS Network Design: Quality of Service in LANs, WANs, and VPNs
Chapter 2: QoS Design Overview

comments.content:
Streaming-Video
When addressing the QoS needs of Streaming-Video traffic, the following guidelines are recommended:

Streaming-Video (whether unicast or multicast) should be marked to DSCP CS4, as designated by the QoS Baseline.

Loss should be no more than 5 percent.

discussion.content:
Interactive-Video
When provisioning for Interactive-Video (video conferencing) traffic, the following guidelines are recommended:

Interactive-Video traffic should be marked to DSCP AF41; excess videoconferencing traffic can be marked down by a policer to AF42 or AF43.

Loss should be no more than 1 percent.

One-way latency should be no more than 150 ms.

Jitter should be no more than 30 ms.

Assign Interactive-Video to either a preferential queue or a second priority queue (when supported); when using Cisco IOS LLQ, overprovision the minimum-priority bandwidth guarantee to the size of the videoconferencing session plus 20 percent. (For example, a 384-kbps videoconferencing session requires 460 kbps of guaranteed priority bandwidth.)

Selected Answer: C
Interactive-Video traffic should be marked to DSCP AF41; excess videoconferencing traffic can be marked down by a policer to AF42 or AF43.

Loss should be no more than 1 percent.

One-way latency should be no more than 150 ms.

Jitter should be no more than 30 ms.

Source: https://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=357102&seqNum=2

Streaming-Video
When addressing the QoS needs of Streaming-Video traffic, the following guidelines are recommended:

 Streaming-Video (whether unicast or multicast) should be marked to DSCP CS4, as designated by the QoS Baseline.

 Loss should be no more than 5 percent.

 Latency should be no more than 4 to 5 seconds (depending on the video application's buffering capabilities).

 There are no significant jitter requirements.

discussion.content:
Just DTMF config on SIP Trunk :
SIP Trunk DTMF Options
No Preference: CUCM will pick the DTMF method to negotiate DTMF, so an MTP is not required for the call. If Cisco Unified Communications Manager has no choice but to allocate an MTP (if the Media Termination Point Required check box is checked), SIP trunk will negotiate DTMF to RFC2833.

RFC 2833: CUCM makes every effort to negotiate RFC2833 regardless of MTP usage. Will fallback to OOB if needed.
OOB and RFC 2833: If both out of band and RFC2833 should be used for DTMF.

Selected Answer: D
Checked in my lab and there are no such options under SIP Profile nor under Regions. The dial peer does allow for configuring DTMF, hence D is correct.
The answer is D.

questions.question_text: An administrator is configuring a new Cisco UCM with PSTN capabilities. Due to bandwidth constraints, audio compression is used on the codec. DTMF must work as expected because the customer is calling many call centers where the users must select options in the call. Where is DTMF out-of-band in a CCM 12.5 with SIP-based gateway configured?

choices.C: in regions on the Cisco UCM where you set the appropriate codec to use
choices.D: in the dial peer on the Cisco IOS router
choices.A: in the DTMF setting under SIP profile on the Cisco Unified Border Element
choices.B: in DTMF settings in the audio codec preference list under regions in the Cisco UCM

questions.question_text: What are two reasons that AF41 is marked for the audio and video channels of a video call? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
Corporate QoS Baseline standard, which requires that the audio and video channels of a video call both be marked as CoS 4 (IP Precedence 4 or PHB AF41). The reasons for this recommendation include, but are not limited to, the following:
• To preserve lip-sync between the audio and video channels
• To provide separate classes for audio-only calls and video calls
Cisco Collaboration System 12.x Solution Reference Network Designs SRND
Chapter 3: Network Infrastructure

Selected Answer: CD
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucm/srnd/collab10/collab10/netstruc.html

Selected Answer: CD
QoS Marking Differences Between Video Calls and Voice-Only Calls

The voice component of a call can be classified in one of two ways, depending on the type of call in progress. A voice-only telephone call would have its media classified as CoS 5 (IP Precedence 5 or PHB EF), while the voice channel of a video conference would have its media classified as CoS 4 (IP Precedence 4 or PHB AF41). All the Cisco IP Video Telephony products adhere to the Cisco Corporate QoS Baseline standard, which requires that the audio and video channels of a video call both be marked as CoS 4 (IP Precedence 4 or PHB AF41). The reasons for this recommendation include, but are not limited to, the following:

 To preserve lip-sync between the audio and video channels
 To provide separate classes for audio-only calls and video calls

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucm/srnd/collab10/collab10/netstruc.html

All the Cisco IP Video Telephony products adhere to the Cisco Corporate QoS Baseline standard, which requires that the audio and video channels of a video call both be marked as CoS 4 (IP Precedence 4 or PHB AF41). The reasons for this recommendation include, but are not limited to, the following:

 To preserve lip-sync between the audio and video channels
 To provide separate classes for audio-only calls and video calls

choices.B: to give video calls a higher priority than AF41 in the QoS policy
choices.D: to preserve lip synchronization between the audio and video channels
choices.A: to allow high-definition quality calls over low-speed links
choices.C: to provide separate classes for audio calls and video calls
choices.E: to prioritize video over other high-priority traffic classes

questions.question_text: How are network devices monitored in a collaboration network?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Prime Collaboration needs only SNMP read access to collect network device information. SNMP must also be enabled on network devices to allow Prime Collaboration to get information on network devices at configured polling intervals and to receive alerts and faults via trap notification sent by the managed devices.
One thing is Discovery, and another thing is Monitoring.CDP and Ping Sweep are discovery methods. System logs are used for some appliances. For monitoring, is the SNMP method.
CCNP and CCIE Collaboration Core CLCOR 350-801 Official Cert Guide
Chapter 14: DNS, NTP, and SNMP

Selected Answer: D
Checking system logs is not a monitoring method. SNMP should be the answer.

Selected Answer: D
The Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) is an application-layer protocol that uses a call-and-response system to check the status of many types of devices, from switches to printers. SNMP can be used to monitor system status and configuration.

choices.C: The Cisco Discovery Protocol table is shared among devices.
choices.D: Simple Network Managed Protocol is enabled on each device to poll specific values periodically.
choices.A: System logs are collected in a Cisco Prime Collaboration Server.
choices.B: Ping Sweep reports ג€unmanagedג€ state devices.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Display IE (isdn outgoing display-ie) is used mainly to provide the calling name over PRI Trunk. It can be sent in SETUP, ALERTING, or CALLPROC messages.
Also, calling name (isdn supp-service name calling) is considered as supplementary service and therefore it can be carried over Facility IE instead of Display IE. However, the same command should be applied on the terminating gateway in order to decode the Facility IE value as calling name and send the displayed text to the phone (in case of CME) or to CUCM. Else, Facility IE will be forwarded without decode (raw value) and the calling name won’t be displayed since Facility IE isn’t recognized by phone or CUCM. 
Reference: "Caller ID Display over ISDN PRI "
https://community.cisco.com/t5/collaboration-knowledge-base/caller-id-display-over-isdn-pri/ta-p/3162883

nterface Serial0/2/0:23

 no ip address

 encapsulation hdlc

 isdn switch-type primary-ni

 isdn incoming-voice voice

 isdn outgoing display-ie

 no cdp enable
I would say C.

Selected Answer: C
From what I can see online, both C and D are correct, but in the Cisco OCG it has to configure it using "isdn outgoing display-ie", so I'm guessing that's the answer they're looking for.

Selected Answer: D
To set the calling name display parameters sent out on an ISDN serial interface, use the isdn supp-service name calling command in interface configuration mode.
Source: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/voice/command/reference/vr_book/vr_i2.html

comments.content: Actually, D is more limiting, because you must enable the command in the two ends, in the originating gateway and the terminating gateway. In the PSTN cloud, do you have control over the ITSP gateways?, I do not believe it. In order of the context, C is more adequate to the scenario, because you have control over one gateway, no two.

discussion.content:
Reading the doucmentation, both C and D are valid options.

C is more limiting option, so I think the answer is D.

Not all ISDN switch types support the isdn outgoing display-ie command. The following shows the direction dependency by switch type, and this command can be used to override the dependency:
•ETSI (NTT, NET3,and NET5)—Only network-to-user
•DMS—Both ways
•TS014—Only network-to-user
•TS013—Only network-to-user
•1TR6—Only network-to-user 

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/voice/command/reference/vr_book/vr_i2.html

Selected Answer: C
I would say C.
https://community.cisco.com/t5/collaboration-knowledge-base/caller-id-display-over-isdn-pri/ta-p/3162883

D

isdn supp-service name calling
To set the calling name display parameters sent out on an ISDN serial interface, use the isdn supp-service name calling command in interface configuration mode. To disable calling name delivery, use the no form of this command.

isdn supp-service name calling [ie | operation-value-tag | profile {Network Extension operation-value-tag {ecma | iso | local} | ROSE}]

no isdn supp-service name calling
i think answer is C
